name: Molecular Biology
understandings: Molecular biology explains living processes in terms of the chemical substances involved
Carbon atoms can form four covalent bonds allowing for a diversity of stable compounds to exist
Life is based on carbon compounds including carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and nucleic acids
Metabolism is the web of all the enzyme-catalysed reactions in a cell or organism
Anabolism is the synthesis of complex molecules from simpler molecules including formation of macromolecules from monomers by condensation
Catabolism is the breakdown of complex molecules into simpler molecules including hydrolysis of macromolecules
Water molecules are polar and form hydrogen bonds
Hydrogen bonding and dipolarity explain the cohesive, adhesive, thermal and solvent properties of water
applications: Structure and function of cellulose and starch in plants and glycogen in humans
Use of molecular visualization software to compare cellulose, starch and glycogen
Scientific evidence for health risks of trans fats and saturated fatty acids
Lipids are more suitable for long-term energy storage than carbohydrates
Evaluation of evidence and the methods used in obtaining it
Denaturation of proteins by heat or pH change

keyConcepts.definition: A chemical reaction that joins two molecules together by removing water
keyConcepts.importance: Forms polymers from monomers; creates peptide bonds, glycosidic bonds, and ester bonds

keyConcepts.definition: A chemical reaction that breaks bonds between monomers by adding water
keyConcepts.importance: Breaks down polymers for digestion and metabolism

keyConcepts.definition: A biological catalyst, usually a protein, that speeds up metabolic reactions without being permanently changed
keyConcepts.importance: Essential for all metabolic processes; highly specific and regulated

keyConcepts.definition: A weak attraction between a slightly positive hydrogen atom and a slightly negative atom (usually O or N)
keyConcepts.importance: Gives water its unique properties; maintains protein and DNA structure

keyConcepts.definition: The loss of a protein's three-dimensional structure due to disruption of bonds, causing loss of function
keyConcepts.importance: Explains why enzymes stop working at extreme temperatures or pH

keyConcepts.definition: The region on an enzyme where substrate molecules bind and the reaction is catalyzed
keyConcepts.importance: Determines enzyme specificity; shape complementary to substrate

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Enzymes are used up in reactions
commonMisconceptions.correction: Enzymes are catalysts and are not consumed. They can be reused many times for the same reaction.
Denaturation changes protein shape and is often irreversible, but some proteins can refold if conditions return to normal.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All lipids are bad for health
commonMisconceptions.correction: Unsaturated fats are generally beneficial. Only trans fats and excessive saturated fats are linked to health risks.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Carbohydrates are the best energy storage
commonMisconceptions.correction: Lipids store more energy per gram (38 kJ/g vs 17 kJ/g) and are better for long-term storage.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Water is just a simple molecule with no special properties
commonMisconceptions.correction: Water's polarity and hydrogen bonding give it unique properties essential for life (high specific heat, cohesion, solvent properties).

typicalQuestions: Explain how hydrogen bonding contributes to the properties of water

markingNotes: Water properties questions require linking molecular structure to macroscopic properties
Enzyme questions need reference to active site and substrate
Macromolecule comparisons should include specific structural features
Data-based questions often involve interpreting enzyme kinetics graphs
highScoringTips: Always link structure to function in molecular questions
Use specific examples (e.g., amylose vs amylopectin for starch)
For enzyme questions, mention the induced fit model
Reference hydrogen bonding when discussing any macromolecule structure

connections.relationship: Cells are composed of the molecules described in this topic
DNA and genes are nucleic acids covered in molecular biology
Human physiology involves enzyme-catalyzed metabolic reactions
AHL: Metabolism expands on enzyme kinetics and metabolic pathways

understandings: Most enzymes are proteins but some are RNA molecules
Activation energy is needed for a reaction to occur
Enzyme inhibitors can be competitive or non-competitive
Metabolic pathways consist of chains and cycles of enzyme-catalysed reactions
applications: Methods of production of lactose-free milk and its advantages
Use of databases to identify proteins from their primary structure
Determination of Vmax and the Michaelis-Menten constant (Km)

diagrams: Amino acid structure and peptide bond formation
Effect of temperature/pH on enzyme activity graphs
formulas: Energy value: Lipids = 38 kJ/g, Carbohydrates/Proteins = 17 kJ/g
